newsitem.title: ROMANIA: ROMANIA CAR MAKERS, IMPORTERS SLAM NEW ROAD TAX.
newsitem.headline: ROMANIA CAR MAKERS, IMPORTERS SLAM NEW ROAD TAX.

text.p: Romania's main car makers and importers on Tuesday slammed the transport ministry's decision to levy a road tax on motorists, saying it could push local car production and sales to the brink of collapse.
"This move hurts seriously the interests of car producers, importers or users," Paul Schiaucu, head of the Association of Automotive Manufacturers and Importers (APIA), told a news conference.

On Monday the ministry said it would amend a 1996 bill -- which already levies a 10 percent tax on the purchase price of new cars -- and bring in a supplementary road tax in order to create a fund to repair the country's battered roads.

"The extra burden brought by the new taxes is extremely discouraging for all car buyers and threatens producers," said Dan Vardie, vice-president of APIA, which groups the local Dacia Automobile SA and Daewoo Automobile Craiova car makers.
Under the new rules, vehicles with a capacity of up to 1,500 cubic centimetres would be taxed with 50,000 lei a year.
Capacities from 1,500 to 2,000 cc would be taxed with 100,000 lei, while taxes for vehicles with capacities exceeding 2,000 cc would amount to 1.4 million lei.
Romania has some 2.94 registered vehicles of various capacities, APIA data show.
Since the bill was enforced last November, car sales had dropped dramatically in Romania, Vardie said.
Data showed sales for imported and locally-made cars had dropped by 40 percent since January.
"I can't grasp the logic behind these taxes," said Marius Pitigoi, head of the Autorom SA, the sole authorised Mercedes dealer in Romania.
"It looks like someone just played with figures without thinking that any potential buyer already has to pay huge amounts to get a car," Pitigoi said.

The ministry planned to put an estimated 2.5 trillion lei to be grossed from the road taxes into a special fund to finance part of the repairs needed by Romania's roads. Some 70 percent of the country's 14,500 km (9,000 miles) of roads are in bad shape.
